raw_response:
Couscous, when served as a traditional Tunisian Jewish Djerban dish and more broadly North African preparation, appears as a **fluffy mound of small, light, separate granules** of steamed semolina, resembling fine grains of rice but rounder and softer in texture. The **consistency is solid but fluffy**, not soupy or stew-like on its own, made perfect for soaking up accompanying vegetable stews and broths.
